Body:
BC-SPOT-BJT18-COX 
    

      CoxNet Cox News Service budget
      FOR TUESDAY, July 18, 2000
      c. 2000 Cox News Service

   For questions, please call 404-526-5456.

   INTERNATIONAL

   MIDEAST-SUMMIT _ THURMONT, Md. _ Spot coverage of the final
status peace talks between Israel and the Palestinians. The talks
focus on three issues: the future of Jerusalem; borders of a
Palestinian state; and fate of millions of Palestinian refugees
around the world. Developing. (Deans, Cox News Service).

   WAN: Location, Atlanta; Category, International; Subcategory,
Other.

   NOTES: Will move on the NYT Wire in (i) International and (w)
Washington categories.

   NATIONAL

   COVERDELL-SURGERY _ Sen. Paul Coverdell is undergoing surgery
for a cerebral hemorrhage and is in guarded condition, according to
statement released by his office. (Pruitt, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution).

   WITH

   COVERDELL-SIDE _ Exploring the medical issues. (Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   TOBACCO _ Judge reviews motions in the landmark punitive damages
trial of tobacco companies. (Bennett, Palm Beach Post).

   SOFTBALL _ ATLANTA _Two women were hospitalized after a girls
softball game turned into a brawl in Covington Saturday. Rumor is
that one of the brawlers the wife of a higher up in the police
dept. Still checking to see if charges will be filed. (Jones,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   WRITE-VIOLENCE _ WASHINGTON _ Seventh and eighth graders on
Monday are to watch the deposit of a moving collection of 28
stories, poems and essays about violence in the Library of
Congress. The winning entries in the national ``Do the Write Thing
Challenge,'' sponsored by government and business and entered by
more than 18,600 students from 450 schools, are to be accepted by
Education Secretary Richard Riley and library officials. The 28
winners include two Atlantans, Taronda Gibbons, an eighth-grader at
L.J. Price Middle School, and Leo L. Tolin, an eighth-grader from
Young Middle School. (Mollison, Cox News Service). 25.

   With: WRITE-EXCERPTS.

   BRUNSWICK-MARCH _ BRUNSWICK, Ga. _ A march on City Hall is
planned for Monday evening as the result of a July 4 altercation
between police and blacks. Incensed by the mayor's comments that
``rioters were thugs and pimps,'' the marchers vow to defeat him.
March gives focus to long history of grievances against police.
Police and city and county respond. (Atlanta Journal-Constitution).

   EDs: March is skedded for 7 p.m. EDT. Story ETA is 9 p.m. EDT.

   CHARELSTON-BARS _CHARLESTON _ After drunks from downtown
Charleston bars kept wandering into her backyard garden, Nina Liu
installed locks on her two gates. That problem ended. Now the
60-year-old art dealer is among sleep-deprived downtown residents
who are counting on city leaders to clamp down on the racket and
littering, the flower pot smashing and other vandalism they blame
on the late-night bar crowd. The Charleston City Council is
scheduled to consider final approval tonight to an ordinance
requiring the city's bars and clubs to stop selling alcohol at 2
a.m. (Buritt, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   TOWN-NOWATER _ THROCKMORTON, Texas _ Welcome to the tiny town of
Throckmorton, population 1,008. This north Texas town is fast on
its way toward earning the distinction of being the first
incorporated area in Texas to run out of water. With a 90-day
supply left, the residents of Throckmorton are scrambling for
solutions, particularly on how to pay to bring water into the area.
Beginning today, phase one of saving Throckmorton begins as
resident volunteers begin trenching their own pipeline to a nearby
reservoir and laying their own PVC piping. (Harmon, Austin
American-Statesman). 30. WITH PHOTOS and LOCATOR MAP.

   BUSH _ Gov. George W. Bush hints at plans for his pre-convention
ride, telling reporters in Arkansas that he will leave Austin on
the 28th of July and then travel to Arkansas, Missouri, Kentucky,
Ohio, West Virginia and Pennsylvania. He aid that Gov. Huckabee of
Arkansas is not on his short-list, adding that the list is no
longer shrinking and expanding, but not saying when or where he
will announce his running mate. He also unveiled a fatherhood
initiative, the latest in a series of initiatives designed to boost
his compassinate conservative credentials. (Heath, Austin
American-Statesman) 7 p.m.

   POL-TICKER _ A brief roundup of the day's campaign events,
pulled from Cox staff and wire reports. (Cox News Service) ETA: 6
p.m.

   OPED/EDITORIAL

   SCHUETT-COLUMN _ GIBSONBURG, Ohio. Paul Thompson is a pig farmer
on a piece of land three miles west of Stuart, Fla. He and his wife
moved there in 1957. Over the years he's raised and sold hogs, all
the time picking up side jobs to make ends meet. He's been a
carpenter, a commercial fisherman, and a sheriff's deputy. He says
for folks who weren't born rich, it's just what they do to
survive.(Schuett, Cox News Service) MOVED.

   LANE-COLUMN _ DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. _ I am not a mere newspaper
columnist. I provide newspaper column solutions. One must keep up
with the times. Everybody who is anybody.com is a provider of
solutions in these days. People who used to work for the phone
company now provide communications solutions. People who two years
ago built network machinery now provide networking solutions.
(Lane, Daytona Beach News-Journal) MOVED.

   BUSINESS

   COKE-WEAR _ Coca-Cola wants more Europeans to wear what they
drink and drink what they wear. The Atlanta-based beverage giant
will announce today Tuesday that it plans to sell its line of
casualwear and sports-inspired clothing in both Eastern and Western
Europe. (Unger, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 12.

   GAPAC-FORTJAMES _ Georgia-Pacific Group, the No. 2 U.S.
forest-products company, agreed to buy rival Fort James Corp. for
$11.3 billion, becoming the world's biggest tissue maker and
lessening its dependence on the housing market. Georgia-Pacific
will pay $29.60 in cash and 0.2644 share, or about $37.17 a share.
That's 51 percent more than Friday's closing price. It will also
assume $3.5 billion in debt. The company will add Fort James'
Quilted Northern bathroom tissue to its brands that include Brawny
paper towels, surpassing Kimberly-Clark Corp. as the biggest tissue
maker. (Bond, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 15.

   BIZMAGS _ A rundown of the week's financial press. (Walker,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   BELLSOUTH _Through a purchase on the Bogot 9 stock exchange,
CelumUvil BellSouth has acquired 100% of the shares of Cocelco, a
leading company in the provision of wireless communication services
in the western region of Colombia. (Kanell, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution)

   DELTA-LATAM _ ATLANTA _ It's shaping up as a busy fall for Delta
Air Lines in Latin America. The carrier said Monday it will launch
new nonstops between Atlanta and Bogota, Colombia, on Dec. 1. That
will be in addition to three other new Latin routes scheduled to
start this fall: to Santiago, Chile; Leon Mexico; and Los Cabos,
Mexico. The new routes continue Delta's 2-year-old Latin offensive.
(Thurston, Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   TECHNOLOGY

   COXNET PTECH _ (EDS: This is the CoxNet PTECH page for the
current week. This layout is now available.)

   PERSONAL TECHNOLOGY

   Art includes three color photographs and one color illustration

   COXNET PTECH 0715: DELETE PC FEAR _ Are you scared of Web
surfing? Terrified of technology? You are not alone. And there is
help. Getting plugged in to the information revolution is easier
than you think. You may even find that it's fun (Katz, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution.) Art includes a 4-column color photo of
Microsoft's ``Digital Diva'' demonstrating a handheld computer to
two women.

   WITH: TIPS BOX _ A list of tips from Microsoft's ``Digital
Diva'' on how to adapt to new technologies. Art includes a 6-pica
color illustration of a computer.

   WITH: TECHNOBUDDY _ When shopping for a computer, it's a good
idea to shop for technical support, not for performance
specifications. (Husted, Atlanta Journal-Constitution.) Art
includes 1 column color sig of columnist.

   WITH: GADGETS _ Philips has introduced a new clock radio with an
alarm that wakes sleepers gently. (Cummings, Dayton Daily News) Art
includes a 1-column color photo of a clock radio.

   WITH: WEB SURFING _ Backpack? Check. Cast iron skillet? Check.
Laptop? Check. Get the most out of your next camping trip by first
logging on to these terrific Web sites. (Staff, Austin
American-Statesman) Art includes an 18-pica color illustration of
campers inside a computer.

   VIDEO-EDIT _ If you have a camcorder, chances are you've got
dozens of old tapes gathering dust. Most of the stuff on the tapes
is worthless, but you don't throw the tapes away because of the one
or two treasured scenes mixed in with the deck. A digital video
editing machine can help you cull the scenes you want from those
you don't want. And once you've retrieved all the good parts, you
can create highlight videos you'll be proud to show. James
Cummings' gadgets column. (Cummings, Dayton Daily News) WITH PHOTO.
MOVED

   WEB-SECRET _ AUSTIN, Texas _ We had no idea wearing all black
was this crucial. ``All professional attire must be predominantly
(95 percent) black,'' intones the six-page Victoria's Secret dress
code. ``Predominantly black means no bold checks, houndstooth or
wide stripes. Outfits trimmed in another color are acceptable as
long as 95 percent of the outfit is black.'' (Wizda, Austin
American-Statesman) MOVED.

   TECH-PLAYGEAR _ The latest in digital game gear. This week:
Fujifilm MX-2900 (Austin American-Statesman) MOVED.

   TECH-WORKGEAR _ The latest in digital work gear. This week:
ShowOffs. (Austin American-Statesman) MOVED.

   TECH-HOMEGEAR _ The latest in digital home gear. This week:
Net2Phone. (Austin American-Statesman) MOVED.

   TECH-LINK _ Your link to some of the best and most interesting
sites on the Web. This week: myStockOptions.com (Austin
American-Statesman) MOVED.

   TECH-KIDGEAR _ Games for children. This week: Fisher Price's
Grow to Pro Golf. (Austin American-Statesman) MOVED.

   TECH-WEEWEB _ Websites for children. This week: Learn about
careers. (Austin American-Statesman) MOVED.

   TECH-GAMER _ Games for the console and desktop aimed at the
moderate to advanced gamer. This week: Sony Speed Punk. (Austin
American-Statesman) MOVED.

   TECHNOBUDDY_ Popular column about personal computing written for
the average user. This week: Snoop software. (Husted, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution) MOVED.

   TECH-TOOLS _ Software reviews. This week: Computer coding.
(Warner, Atlanta Joch, using MRIs so finely tuned that they can
watch oxygen cells travel within the brain. This, in turn, allows
the scientists to see how specific regions of the brain control
specific actions. And it may ultimately allow doctors to do a
better job of treating brain disorders. (Roser, Austin
American-Statesman). 22. WITH PHOTOS.

   GERMS-TOOCLEAN _ Americans have a nasty habit: too much
cleanliness. We're obsessed with it. And young mothers are the
worst offenders. We disinfect the kitchen counters countless times
a day; we spray Lysol in the bathroom until the fumes are
overpowering. Too much is not a good thing, according to leading
immunologists, especially for infants, whose immune systems need
exposure to help them develop a defense against germs. (Toner,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 20.

   WITH: Photo illustration/examples of some of the anti-germ
products we use too much.

   ANTIBIOTICS _ At LDS hospital in Salt Lake City, researchers ran
an interesting experiment with surprising results: They cut
antibiotic use in half, using a computer-assisted program to
prevent doctors from over-prescribing. And only half as many
patients died. (Toner, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 12.

   ENTERTAINMENT/ARTS

   BOOKS-BOBANVILLE _ It's not that the title of Bo Banville's
autobiography, Bo Doesn't Live Here Anymore, isn't clever. It's a
darn good name, really, for a book about a guy who's lived in 22
states and overseas, gone to 28 schools, and won and lost dozens of
jobs, scores of women and thousands of dollars.

   With mug of him and bookcover. (Folstad, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution). 19.

   BOOKS-RHAPSODY _ Interview with Joe Eszterhazy, who has a new
book, ``American Rhapsody,'' coming out July 18. (Morris, Austin
American-Statesman). WITH PHOTOS.

   BOOKS-ALLISON _ ATLANTA _ For the first time, Emory University's
Summer Writers festival is focusing on the work of one author.
Dorothy Allison, author of ``Bastard Out of Carolina,'' will give
readings and workshops on Wednesday and Thursday. In an interview
from her San Francisco home, Allison talks about her next book and
how she continues to deal with the memories of a tramautic, abusive
childhood in a South Carlolina mill village. ``I've written about
the vindication of poor white trash,'' she says, ``and I am that
vindication. At least in my mother's eyes.'' (O'Briant, Atlanta
Journal-Constitution). 13.

   HOLLOWAY-TVCOLUMN _ Observations on the television industry from
a leading commentator. This week: Flaws with upcoming television
season. (Holloway, Austin American-Statesman) MOVED.

   NEWSSTAND _ Periodicals on the newsstands this week. (O'Briant,
Atlanta Journal-Constitution)

   SPORTS

   GOLF

   GLF-BROPEN-DALY _ Five Years After: John Daly shocked the
golfing world five years ago at St. Andrews, when he came out of
nowhere with his booming drives to win the British Open. That was
then. Daly returned to the site on Monday, overweight, unshaven and
almost ragged looking, hoping that lightning will strike again.
(Sheeley, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). 22.

   FOOTBALL

   FBN-FALCONS-JEFFERSON _ The Falcons believe that they have found
the deep threat that was missing from last year's team in receiver
Shawn Jefferson. Jefferson was signed as a free agent in February
and is expected to make a huge impact on the team this season.
(Winkeljohn, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). WITH PHOTO.

   COWBOYS _ WICHITA FALLS, Texas _ Dallas Cowboys head Coach Dave
Campo talks about his expectations, what he hopes to accomplish and
how he feels about his job as the new coach. The Cowboys report to
training camp in Wichita Falls Monday. Practice begins Tuesday.
(Cantu, Atlanta Journal-Constitution).

   CYCLING

   CYC-TOUR-LANCE _ The Tour de France took a much needed day off
Monday before riders began their final week of cycling. But Lance
Armstrong, who has dominated the race the past two weeks, wasn't
content

   Cox Washington Bureau:

   News editor Art Dalglish, 202-887-8338, artd(at)coxnews.com

   Foreign editor Rick Christie, 202-887-8316, rickc(at)coxnews.com

   Bureau chief Andy Alexander, 202-887-8334, andya(at)coxnews.com

   Photo Editor Rick McKay 202-887-8348, rickm(at)coxnews.com

   GOLF

   FOOTBALL

   FBN-FALCONS-JEFFERSON _ The Falcons believe that they have found
the deep threat that was missing from last year's team in receiver
Shawn Jefferson. Jefferson was signed as a free agent in February
and is expected to make a huge impact on the team this season.
(Winkeljohn, Atlanta Journal-Constitution). WITH PHOTO.

   COWBOYS _ WICHITA FALLS, Texas _ Dallas Cowboys head Coach Dave
Campo talks about his expectations, what he hopes to accomplish and
how he feels about his job as the new coach. The Cowboys report to
training camp in Wichita Falls Monday. Practice begins Tuesday.
(Cantu, Atlanta Journal-Constitution).
